facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 580 of 1962 is an appeal from the judgment and decree dated May 1, 1961, of the Madras High Court in Writ Petition No. 975 of 1959.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 580 of 1962. Appeal from the judgment and decree dated May 1, 1961, of the Madras High Court in Writ Petition No. 975 of 1959.

facts.text: The appeal comes before the Supreme Court by virtue of a certificate of fitness granted by the High Court of Madras under Art. 133(1)(c) of the Constitution.

anchor.surface_text: The Judgment of the Court was delivered by AYYANGAR, J.-This appeal companyes before us by virtue of a certificate of fitness granted by the High Court of Madras under Art. 133 1  c  of the Constitution against its judgment dismissing a petition filed by the appellant under Art. 226 of the Constitution seeking a writ of prohibition against the Corporation of Madras challenging the companystitutional validity.

facts.text: Appellant filed a petition under Art. 226 seeking writ of prohibition against Corporation of Madras challenging constitutional validity of notice requiring payment of profession tax.

anchor.surface_text: This appeal companyes before us by virtue of a certificate of fitness granted by the High Court of Madras under Art. 133 1  c  of the Constitution against its judgment dismissing a petition filed by the appellant under Art. 226 of the Constitution seeking a writ of prohibition against the Corporation of Madras challenging the companystitutional validity. of a numberice requiring the appellant to pay profession tax.

facts.text: Appellant held office as the last Governor-General of India.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant held office as the last Governor-General of India.

facts.text: Under s. 3 of Central Act XXX of 1951, appellant is entitled to a pension of Rs. 15,000/- per annum and has been drawing this sum residing in the city of Madras.

anchor.surface_text: Under s. 3 of Central Act XXX of 1951 the appellant is entitled to a pension of Rs. 15,000/- per annum and has been drawing this sum residing in the city of Madras.

facts.text: Corporation of Madras demanded profession tax from appellant under s. 111(1)(b) of the City Municipal Act, 1919 for the year 1958-1959 on ground of residence within city and drawing pension.

anchor.surface_text: The Corporation of Madras-the first respondent before us demanded profession tax from the appellant under s. 111 1  b  of the City Municipal Act, 1919 hereinafter called the Act for the year 1958-1959 on the ground of the appellants residence within the city for the period therein specified and his drawing the pension to which he was entitled.

facts.text: Appellant addressed communication to Corporation asserting demand illegal as pensioner does not fall under profession, trade, calling or employment.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant addressed a companymunication to the Corporation asserting that this demand was illegal as the Corporation was empowered by the relevant companystitutional provisions merely to levy a tax on a profession, trade, calling or employment and that as he as a pensioner did number fall under any of these classes, the said demand was illegal.

facts.text: Authorities of Corporation insisted on compliance with demand on ground that under express terms of Act persons in receipt of pensions liable to tax.

anchor.surface_text: The authorities of the Corporation, however, insisted on companypliance with the demand on the ground that under the express terms of the Act persons in receipt of pensions were also liable to the tax.

facts.text: Appellant filed writ petition impleading State of Madras as respondent as validity of State Act impugned.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant thereupon filed a writ petition for the relief already set out, and as the validity of the State Act was impugned impleaded the State of Madras also as a respondent.

facts.text: Madras High Court dismissed appellant's writ petition upholding validity of levy.

anchor.surface_text: against its judgment dismissing a petition filed by the appellant under Art. 226 of the Constitution seeking a writ of prohibition against the Corporation of Madras challenging the companystitutional validity.

facts.text: Madras City Municipal Act (Act IV of 1919) received assent of Governor on March 26, 1919, Governor-General in June 1919, came into force on publication in Gazette in June 1919.

anchor.surface_text: The Act received the assent of the Governor on March 26, 1919, of the Governor-General in June, 1919 and came into force-on publication in the Gazette which was in the same month.

facts.text: Section 111(1) of 1919 Act included Explanation 2 deeming person in receipt of pension as holding an appointment.

anchor.surface_text: Explanation 2 A person in receipt of a pension paid from any source shall be deemed to be a person holding an appointment within the meaning of this section.

facts.text: Madras City Municipal Amendment Act X of 1936 came into force on 14th April 1936, substituted new s.111 deleting Explanation 2, added clause (b) for pensioners residing not less than 60 days.

anchor.surface_text: The next change in the relevant provision was effected by Madras City Municipal Amendment Act, 193,6  Madras Act X of 1936  which came into force on 14th April 1936. By this amendment a new section-s. III was substituted ,for the old one just set out, and under this Explanation  2  was deleted and the substituted provision ran III 1 .

facts.text: Corporation of Madras passed resolution on March 31, 1937 to levy profession tax from April 1, 1937 at specified rates.

anchor.surface_text: The Corporation of Madras availed itself of the provisions of s. 98-A and after the issue of the numberices prescribed by it passed a resolution at a meeting held on March 31, 1937 to levy inter alia profession tax for the year 1937-38 at -the rates which were specified in the resolution.

facts.text: Schedule IV amended in 1942 by notification under s.347(3), effective from April 1, 1942, changing classes based on half-yearly income.

anchor.surface_text: The lacuna in the enactment was Apparently numbericed in 1942 when by a numberification in the Official gazette the Schedule was amended in exercise of the powers companyferred on Government by s. 347 3  of the Act. Under the amendment instead of the words Persons holding any appointment or persons exercising profession, trade or calling etc. the classes Were divided, on the basis of the half yearly income received by the individual specified in s. 111 1 . This amendment to the Schedule was directed to companye into force from April 1, 1942.

facts.text: Rates of tax increased in 1950, 1958 and 1961.

anchor.surface_text: only the rate of tax has been progressively increased first in 1950, then in 1958 and again in 1961

facts.text: Corporation continued to assess and collect profession tax on pensioners notwithstanding apparent inapplicability after 1936 amendment.

anchor.surface_text: Notwith- standing the apparent inapplicability of the rules in Schedule IV to the levy of profession tax on pensioners, the Corporation companytinued to assess pensioners to the said tax and companylected the same.

facts.text: Supreme Court judgment delivered by AYYANGAR, J. on March 3, 1964.

anchor.surface_text: March 3, 1964. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by AYYANGAR, J.-

facts.text: Supreme Court holds that tax on pensioners was not lawfully levied immediately prior to commencement of Part III of Government of India Act, 1935, due to break in levy from April 1936 to March 1937.

anchor.surface_text: If the statutory charge to profession tax imposed on pensioners by the Act of 1919, was lifted by the Act of 1936, and the tax again came into operation only on 1st April, 1937, it would follow that there was numberlevy of the tax immediately before the companymencement of Part III of the Government of India Act, 1935, so as to bring it within the saving in s. 143 2  of that Act.

facts.text: Supreme Court holds that between 1st April 1937 and 1st April 1942, tax not lawfully levied on pensioners due to lacuna in Schedule IV rules.

anchor.surface_text: Under s. 111 1  as amended, the tax companyld be levied only in accordance with the rules in Schedule IV and as those rules did number make a provision for the levy of a tax on pensioners, it would follow that the tax was number being lawfully levied on them.

facts.text: Appeal succeeds; appellant entitled to writ of prohibition against Corporation from enforcing demand.

anchor.surface_text: The appeal accordingly succeeds and the appellant is held entitled to the relief prayed by him in the, filed in the High Court, viz., a writ of Prohibition against the respondent-Corporation from enforcing the demand.

facts.text: Corporation levied tax on pensioners despite changes, but court finds no lawful pre-1937 levy saved under s.143(2) GOI Act 1935 or Art.277 Constitution.

anchor.surface_text: Learned Counsel for the Appellant submits that this is in effect a new levy-a levy of a tax which was number legally in existence on 31st March, 1937, and if this levy companyld number be supported as being sanctioned by s. 143 2  of the Government of India Act, 1935

facts.text: No tax charge imposed between April 1936 and 31st March 1937 after repeal of original s.111.

anchor.surface_text: In other words by reason of the repeal of the original section III, the statutory charge to tax on pensions ceased in April 1936. A charge was imposed again under the resolution -of the Council effective from 1st April, 1937, so that between April 1936 to 31st March, 1937, numbercharge was imposed by virtue of any law.

facts.text: Residence in city for not less than 60 days made condition for liability of pensioners under amended s.111(1)(b).

anchor.surface_text: b  resides in the city for number less than sixty days in the aggregate and is in receipt of any pension or income from investments, shall pay in addition to any licence fee that may be leviable under this Act, a half yearly tax

holdings.text: The Corporation is not entitled to levy profession tax on pensioners in respect of pensions received by them as it is not saved under Article 277 or section 143(2) of the Government of India Act, 1935.

anchor.surface_text: the question for consideration is whether the 1st respondent Corporation is entitled to levy a tax on pensioners in respect of the pensions received by them.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No lawful levy prior to Constitution due to break in charge from 1936-1937 and lacuna in Schedule IV until 1942; not within Entry 60 but tax on income.

holdings.text: There was no levy of profession tax on pensioners immediately before the commencement of Part III of the Government of India Act, 1935, as the statutory charge was lifted by the 1936 amendment and reimposed by resolution only from April 1, 1937.

anchor.surface_text: We consider this submission well founded. If the statutory charge to profession tax imposed on pensioners by the Act of 1919, was lifted by the Act of 1936, and the tax again came into operation only on 1st April, 1937, it would follow that there was nolevy of the tax immediately before the commencement of Part III of the Government of India Act, 1935, so as to bring it within the saving in s. 143 2  of that Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Repeal of original s.111 removed charge in April 1936; new charge via council resolution from 1937 creates break; power to levy not equivalent to levy being imposed.

holdings.text: Profession tax on pensioners was not lawfully levied between April 1, 1937, and April 1, 1942, due to lacuna in Schedule IV rules which did not provide for pensioners after deletion of Explanation 2.

anchor.surface_text: The conclusion we have reached as to the effect of the amendment to s. 111 by Act X of 1936, and of the tax being imposed by resolution of the Council from 1st April, 1937 not being a tax which was being lawfully levied immediately prior to 1st April, 1942, is reinforced by reference to the rules in Schedule IV which remained unamended till 1942. Under s. 111 1  as amended, the tax could be levied only in accordance with the rules in Schedule IV and as those rules did not make a provision for the levy of a tax on pensioners, it would follow that the tax was not being lawfully levied on them.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Schedule IV rules referenced appointments or professions; deletion of deeming provision for pensioners made rules inapplicable; General Clauses Act s.18 does not remedy.

holdings.text: A tax on receipt of pension is not a tax on profession, trade, calling or employment under Entry 60 List II but a tax on income under Entry 82 List I.

anchor.surface_text: item 60 in the State List in Schedule VII of the Constitution reading Taxes on profession, trades, callings and employments. Being a pensioner cannot be a profession [...] is nothing but a tax on income falling within Entry 82 of the Union list.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Entry 60 covers present carrying on of profession etc.; pension is for past services, received without current employment; respondent's past employment argument untenable.

holdings.text: Article 277, being a special provision for pre-existing taxes, prevails over the general provision in Article 372 continuing existing laws.

anchor.surface_text: It is settled law that a special provision should be given effect to the extent of its scope, leaving the general provision to control cases where the special provision does not apply. ... Art. 372 must be read subject to Art. 277.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Specialia generalibus derogat; Art.277 confined to taxes lawfully levied pre-Constitution; follows South India Corporation precedent.

holdings.text: Mere existence of power to impose tax by resolution does not mean the tax was being lawfully levied for purposes of s.143(2) GOI Act 1935.

anchor.surface_text: The mere existence of a power to bring a tax into operation, cannot, as pointed out, be equated with a tax which was being lawfully levied before Part III of the Government of India Act, 1935.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.143(2) requires tax 'being lawfully levied'; follows Town Municipal Committee, Amravati precedent.

holdings.text: Section 142-A(1) GOI Act 1935 (corresponding to Art.276(1)) protects only taxes on professions etc., not taxes on income disguised as profession tax.

anchor.surface_text: This section would assist the respondent only if tax imposed were one on a profession... but where the tax imposed is one not on a profession, etc. at all, it does not mean that the State might levy a tax on income and call it profession tax.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual limit to taxes 'in respect of professions'; inapplicable to invalid subject like income tax.

holdings.text: The appeal succeeds and appellant is entitled to writ of prohibition against the Corporation from enforcing the demand for profession tax.

anchor.surface_text: The appeal accordingly succeeds and the appellant is held entitled to the relief prayed by him in the, filed in the High Court, viz., a writ of Prohibition against the respondent-Corporation from enforcing the demand.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Cumulative effect of no saved pre-existing levy and substantive invalidity as tax on income.

anchor.surface_text: The Town Municipal Committee, Amravati v. Ram Chandra Vasudeo Chimote and Another, etc.  1  in which judgment has been pronounced today and it is unnecessary to re-examine the same. The mere existence of a power to bring a tax into operation, cannot, as pointed out, be equated with a tax  1  1964 6 S.C.R. 947.

precedents.cited_proposition: mere existence of a power to bring a tax into operation cannot be equated with a tax which was being lawfully levied prior to the commencement of Part III of the Government of India Act, 1935

anchor.surface_text: S. 142-A 1  which companyresponds to Art. 276 1  of the Constitution enacted Notwithstanding anything in section one hundred of this Act, numberProvincial law relating to taxes for the benefit of a Province or of a municipality, district board, local board or other local authority therein in respect of professions, A.I.R. 1964 S.C. 207.

anchor.surface_text: We consider this submission well founded. If the statutory charge to profession tax imposed on pensioners by the Act of 1919, was lifted by the Act of 1936, and the tax again came into operation only on 1st April, 1937, it would follow that there was nolevy of the tax immediately before the commencement of Part III of the Government of India Act, 1935, so as to bring it within the saving in s. 143 2  of that Act.

anchor.surface_text: The conclusion we have reached as to the effect of the amendment to s. 111 by Act X of 1936, and of the tax being imposed by resolution of the Council from 1st April, 1937 not being a tax which was being lawfully levied immediately prior to 1st April, 1942, is reinforced by reference to the rules in Schedule IV which remained unamended till 1942. Under s. 111 1  as amended, the tax could be levied only in accordance with the rules in Schedule IV and as those rules did not make a provision for the levy of a tax on pensioners, it would follow that the tax was not being lawfully levied on them.
The appeal accordingly succeeds and the appellant is held entitled to the relief prayed by him in the, filed in the High Court, viz., a writ of Prohibition against the respondent-Corporation from
